content: Singaporean politician (born 1958) **Amy Khor Lean Suan** ([Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters): 许连碹; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Xǔ Liánxuàn*; born 23 February 1958) is a Malaysian-born Singaporean former politician who served as [Senior Minister of State for Transport](/wiki/Ministry_of_Transport_(Singapore)) and [Senior Minister of State for Sustainability and the Environment](/wiki/Ministry_of_Sustainability_and_the_Environment) from 2020 to 2025. A member of the governing [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party) (PAP), she was the [Member of Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore#Members_of_Parliament) (MP) for the Hong Kah North division of [Hong Kah Group Representation Constituency](/wiki/Hong_Kah_Group_Representation_Constituency) (GRC) between 2001 and 2011 and [Hong Kah North Single Member Constituency](/wiki/Hong_Kah_North_Single_Member_Constituency) (SMC) between 2011 and 2025. Prior to entering politics, Khor was a [valuer](/wiki/Real_estate_appraisal) at the [Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore](/wiki/Inland_Revenue_Authority_of_Singapore) (IRAS), senior lecturer at the [National University of Singapore](/wiki/National_University_of_Singapore), and executive director at [Knight Frank](/wiki/Knight_Frank). She made her political debut in the [2001 general election](/wiki/2001_Singaporean_general_election) as part of a five-member PAP team contesting in Hong Kah GRC. ## Education Khor was educated at Alexandra Hill Primary School, [Raffles Girls' School](/wiki/Raffles_Girls%27_School) and [Raffles Institution](/wiki/Raffles_Institution) before she went to the [National University of Singapore](/wiki/National_University_of_Singapore), where she completed a [Bachelor of Science](/wiki/Bachelor_of_Science) in estate management in 1981. In 1988, she completed a [Master of Business Administration](/wiki/Master_of_Business_Administration) at [San Jose State University](/wiki/San_Jose_State_University). In 1997, she completed a [Doctor of Philosophy](/wiki/Doctor_of_Philosophy) in land management at the [University of Reading](/wiki/University_of_Reading). ## Career Khor was a [valuer](/wiki/Real_estate_appraisal) at the Property Tax Division of the [Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore](/wiki/Inland_Revenue_Authority_of_Singapore) from 1981 to 1987, before she became a senior lecturer at the [National University of Singapore](/wiki/National_University_of_Singapore) from 1989 to 1999. From 1999 to 2004, she was an executive director at [Knight Frank](/wiki/Knight_Frank). ### Political career Khor entered politics when she contested as part of a five-member [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party) (PAP) team in the [2001 general election](/wiki/2001_Singaporean_general_election) in [Hong Kah GRC](/wiki/Hong_Kah_Group_Representation_Constituency). The PAP team won with 79.74% of the vote against the [Singapore Democratic Party](/wiki/Singapore_Democratic_Party), and Khor thus became a Member of Parliament representing the [Hong Kah North](/wiki/Hong_Kah) ward of Hong Kah GRC. On 12 August 2004, she was appointed Mayor of the [South West District](/wiki/South_West_Community_Development_Council) and held this position until 26 May 2014. During the [2006 general election](/wiki/2006_Singaporean_general_election), Khor joined a five-member PAP team contesting in Hong Kah GRC again and they won by an uncontested walkover this time. On 30 May 2006, she was appointed [Senior Parliamentary Secretary](/wiki/Parliamentary_secretary) at the [Ministry of the Environment and Water Resources](/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Environment_and_Water_Resources). On 1 April 2007, she was appointed [Deputy Government Whip](/wiki/Whip_(politics)) and held this position until 30 September 2015. On 1 November 2010, she was promoted from Senior Parliamentary Secretary to [Minister of State](/wiki/Minister_of_State#Minor_government_ranks) at the Ministry of the Environment and Water Resources. In the [2011 general election](/wiki/2011_Singaporean_general_election), Khor contested as a solo PAP candidate in the newly formed [Hong Kah North SMC](/wiki/Hong_Kah_North_Single_Member_Constituency) and won with 70.61% of the vote against the [Singapore People's Party](/wiki/Singapore_People%27s_Party)'s [Sin Kek Tong](/wiki/Sin_Kek_Tong). She was appointed Minister of State at the [Ministry of Health](/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Singapore)) on 21 May 2011 and given an additional appointment as Minister of State at the [Ministry of Manpower](/wiki/Ministry_of_Manpower_(Singapore)) on 1 August 2012. On 1 September 2013, Khor was promoted to Senior Minister of State. During the [2015 general election](/wiki/2015_Singaporean_general_election), Khor retained her parliamentary seat in Hong Kah North SMC after winning 74.76% of the vote against the [Singapore People's Party](/wiki/Singapore_People%27s_Party)'s [Ravi Philemon](/wiki/Ravi_Philemon). After the election, she became Senior Minister of State at the [Ministry of the Environment and Water Resources](/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Environment_and_Water_Resources) and [Ministry of Health](/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Singapore)). In the [2020 general election](/wiki/2020_Singaporean_general_election), Khor retained her parliamentary seat in Hong Kah North SMC after winning 60.99% of the vote against the [Progress Singapore Party](/wiki/Progress_Singapore_Party)'s Gigene Wong. On 27 July 2020, she was appointed Senior Minister of State at the [Ministry of Transport](/wiki/Ministry_of_Transport_(Singapore)) and [Ministry of Sustainability and the Environment](/wiki/Ministry_of_Sustainability_and_the_Environment). In April 2025, Khor announced that she would step down at the [2025 general election](/wiki/2025_Singaporean_general_election) and retire from politics. ## Personal life Khor has preaxial (radial) [polydactyly](/wiki/Polydactyly) (growth of extra thumbs) on both hands. She is a Christian and is married with three children. - Amy Khor on [Facebook](/wiki/Facebook_(identifier)) - Amy Khor on [Parliament of Singapore](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore) [Parliament of Singapore](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore)Preceded by **Member of Parliament for [Hong Kah GRC](/wiki/Hong_Kah_GRC)** 2001 – 2011**Constituency abolished** **New constituency** **Member of Parliament for [Hong Kah North SMC](/wiki/Hong_Kah_North_SMC)** 2011 – present**Constituency abolished** Government officesPreceded by[Yu-Foo Yee Shoon](/wiki/Yu-Foo_Yee_Shoon) **[Mayor of the South West district](/wiki/South_West_CDC)** 2004 – 2014Succeeded by[Low Yen Ling](/wiki/Low_Yen_Ling)
